content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

Here is an example of how you can do this in Julia:

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits{T<:Real}
    value::T
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, fwu::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, "$(fwu.value) $(fwu.unit)")
end
```

In this code block, `Base.show` is a function that takes an IO stream and an instance of the struct FloatWithUnits as arguments. It then prints out the value and unit fields in the format "1.8 meters". The `T<:Real` indicates that the type parameter T must be a subtype of Real (i.e., it can be any real number).

You can use this function like so:

```julia
fwu = FloatWithUnits(1.8, "meters")
println(fwu)  # Outputs: 1.8 meters
```
